utterances: I got a job.
A full time job.
Yep, I got hired in July.
Pay is good.
It's local and close to home.
Kenny was hired at Sapa, a Swedish company that took over the aluminum extrusion plant once owned by Alcoa.
You can't beat having steady work, says Kenny.
The anxiety and stress have lifted.

And anybody that loses their job or doesn't have a job will tell you, when you don't have the money, you're always worrying about how you're going to afford to pay this and how you're going to afford to pay for that.
It gets stressful.
It gets real stressful.
But now that I've got a job, I'm more - more relaxed.
With Kenny now working full time, his wife Jill was able to quit her job as a beautician.
She's now spending a lot more time caring for their youngest son and worrying a lot less.
The biggest thing for me was having insurance for my family.
That was even more important to me than the money - you know, having some health issues and that, it was hard not to have an insurance.
Without his GED, Kenny says he'd still be looking for a job.
Even the fast food place that hired him back when he dropped out of high school won't hire anyone these days without a GED or a high school diploma.
(Unintelligible) help you?
Yeah, I'd like two black coffees please.
Well, look; I think that they have sort of staggered around trying to eliminate the Affordable Care Act in the last two years.
They have approached it with the most politically backward way.
The first time they did it, which was they led with the one element that people truly loved about Obamacare from the very beginning.
I'll tell you a quick story.
The existing conditions.
Yes.
I'll tell you a very quick story.
We, during 2009 and '10, were doing some research polling in focus groups for a major advocacy group that was trying to stop the rise of Obamacare.

And the thing we discovered right off the bat - Republicans, Democrats, black, white, liberal, conservative, independent - every single demographic group desperately wanted pre-existing condition coverage.
They'd all had a story about it.
They'd all had a painful experience about it or knew someone who had.
And so when the Trump administration tried to kill it the first time, they led with that.
So they led with their chin on it and got knocked down pretty hard.
You know, even their own Republicans in Congress were like, no, thank you.
And I think you're going to end up with that taking front and center now.
I think that, for all of its flaws, the Affordable Care Act has led to a lot of people becoming accustomed to, particularly, having the pre-existing coverage.
And so I think there's a political difficulty ahead in terms of how do you get people who are up for re-election in 18 months to jump on that grenade?
Well, how do they?
I mean, clearly, there are those in the president's orbit who believe that this is the right political move, I mean, that this is perhaps what Trump's base wants.
Is it?
The irony of this is that Trump's base has about a fair amount of uptake on Obamacare-type programs.
And I think that they're going to end up - you know, like all government programs, they are extraordinarily controversial at first.
And whether they are good or bad for the economy, people who come to see them as a right or a benefit expect to keep that right or benefit.
And so I think you're going to end up with that as the difficulty here.
And look; there's an ideological component inside the Trump administration that, quite frankly, would really, really like to get rid of Obamacare as a promises-kept checklist item.
But there is nothing, you know - there's no repeal-and-replace question here.
This is just a pure elimination question.
There's no serious health care plan coming down the pike right now in Congress on either side.
Nothing that Democrats want would pass the Senate, but then the Senate wants to pass the House.
So we're going to be, basically, throwing the health care markets into some enormous chaos.
And meanwhile, the Democrats are more than happy to talk about this issue.
It's a political gift for them ahead of the election.
Absolutely.
They did so in 2018, very successfully.
Republican strategist Rick Wilson - he worked for George H.W.
Bush's campaign and in George W.
Bush's administration.
Thanks so much for your time this morning.
We appreciate it.
You're very welcome.
This is Day to Day.
I am Madeline Brand.
I am Alex Chadwick.
Sweet 16, that is the name of this round.
Sixteen teams left in the NCAA Men's Basketball Tournament.
Actually, not 16 anymore because they played some games yesterday, they are playing more today.
Here with us is Kevin Blackistone.
He is a columnist with AOL Sports and a commentator for ESPN.
He is with us from our Washington studios.
OK, I think the game people are really waiting for this weekend is the one that happens at seven o'clock Eastern Time tonight.
And that is Wisconsin, University of Wisconsin versus Davidson.
Davidson is a small college from North Carolina.
Not one that we think of as a big basketball power although this is not their first time in the tournament.
And tell us about the Davidson story and this particular player.
They really epitomize what the NCAA Tournament is all about because they are small school and they are playing the role of David.
And they have slain a couple of Goliaths, most recently Georgetown last week.
And they have been led by a kid in the name of Stephen Curry who is the son of the long time NBA player Dell Curry who is also a stand-out basketball player from Virginia Tech.
And he is slight of frame, but certainly big of heart.
And he is averaging, just in the second half of this tournament, 27 and a half points.
And that absolutely shocked Georgetown out of the NCAA Tournament last weekend with a scoring display, a shooting display that hasn't been seen in the NCAA Tournament in probably a couple of decades.
He is, when you say slight of frame, this is a large person for a normal human being, right?
He is five-eleven but in basketball terms, that is nothing.
Exactly.

He is just a wisp of a basketball player, and the funny thing is that he is so smallish that most of the big schools didn't recruit him despite the pedigree in his family of Dell Curry as his father who played for such a long time in the NBA.
So many schools passed him by, and he is making all of those schools pay right now.
Well, do you think that this guy is going on to a career in the pros?
Is he going to follow his dad into the NBA?
You know, his father was a much bigger player, much more physically imposing.

I don't think that this is the type of kid who necessarily will get drafted, but given the show that he is putting on offensively in the NCAA Tournament and against the Georgetown team by the way which is noted for its defense.
And in 68 consecutive NCAA tournament games had never allowed one player to score 30 or more points against them.
Given that Stephen Curry has done that, I think that some NBA team certainly down the line is going to have to give him a look.
And it very well maybe the team that his father works for, the Charlotte Bobcats, because he is in the front office and his job is, in part, is to scout young talent for the team.
Well, he doesn't have to look far.
No, right across the dinner table.
Kevin Blackstone of AOL Sports and ESPN.
Kevin, thank you.
Thank you.
We're going to take the next few minutes to remember the woman being called the godmother of Title IX.
Bernice Sandler died this past weekend at the age of 90.
She was the catalyst for the landmark civil rights legislation that made it illegal for schools receiving federal funds to discriminate on the basis of sex.
NPR's Tom Goldman reports.
We drive up to the window.
A woman walks in front of Kenny's car and waves.
I know her.
Yeah.
Kenny says it's no longer embarrassing running into people he grew up with, people who've seen him struggle and jobless.
These days he can afford to eat out maybe once a week, buy a new shirt or a blouse for his wife.
Still, Kenny says hard times have taught him to be frugal.
Bills come first.
The house gets paid first.
The major things.
You pay your major things first.
Whatever's left over...
You save, says Kenny.
As we pull out of the parking lot, it's clear that the story of Schuylkill County is not nearly as upbeat as Kenny's.
We drive past empty shopping centers, strip malls and old abandoned warehouses - all signs of a prolonged, struggling economy.
Although farther down the road there is a company that makes bird feed that's hiring.
So is the small local lumber company.
A new Kohl's department store is going to open here soon.
People without a high school diploma or a GED, of course, need not apply.
But even if you have one, neither will guarantee a living wage, says Sharon Angelo.
She runs Career Link, a job counseling and referral center in Schuylkill County.
The economy has picked up slightly.
But what we're noticing too is you may have employers that pay one salary in Schuylkill County and just go across the border to another facility of theirs and find out that you could get paid more.
With so many people looking for jobs around here, Angelo says, employers don't have to offer more than the minimum wage.
Kenny says that's why so many of his friends have left to find something better.
I'm not saying minimum paying jobs are bad, but if you're going to raise a family or if you want things in life, minimum paying jobs just don't cut it.
I mean they just don't.
It's hard to say when or if wages will improve in this economy.
But Sharon Angelo says the one thing that seems to be getting worse is the high school dropout rate.
She's seeing a lot more dropouts.
I'm talking people who are 17 through 21 years of age.
They don't have enough room to accommodate the number of people who are looking for a GED.
Angelo says for every Kenny Buchanan who has come back for his GED and found a good paying job, there are dozens of dropouts who are unemployable.
I think it's sad.
I do.
Kenny says he's lucky.
You can't guarantee nothing in life.
But yeah.
Yeah, I'm fortunate.
